newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian Grain - Price slump accelerates.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian Grain - Price slump accelerates.

text.p: Australian grain prices continued to fall heavily last week as markets grimly celebrated the big world crop and traders looked for further price declines.

Cash wheat prices fell by up to A$15.00 a tonne for the benchmark Australian Standard White (ASW), and while futures prices fell less than this the prospect at week's end was for a continued market slide.

Australian wheat prices have now fallen by more than A$40.00 a tonne in the last three months as Australia consolidated its own big 1996/97 grain crop and as an expected poor crop in the U.S. and elsewhere gradually emerged much bigger than thought.
Futures broker Ben Suttie of C, A & L Bell Commodities said A$120.00 a tonne for January 1997 futures was now a prospect, against the contract's Friday settlement close of A$163.50.

"I think we're (prices are) going to weaken as we go into harvest. We've got a huge crop out there. Bar a frost the crop's going to be huge," he said. "(Cash) ASW delivered Newcastle (on Friday was) A$155.00 offer - A$120 here we come."
Guy Allen of GrainCorp saw last week's Australian market fall as largely reflecting Australian concern over European export subsidies.
Rain toward the end of the week in wheatgrowing areas added to the bearish news, he said.
End users were still not coming to the market, he said.
Peter Howard of New England Agricultural Traders described last week's market as an "absolute capitulation" and as having turned "extremely ugly".

Feed barley had lost A$20 a tonne over the past two weeks to reach a bidding quote of A$114.00 a tonne on Friday, while the wheat market had virtually dried up with no farmers considering selling at present prices, Howard said.
The sorghum market in the past week was also very thin, with old crop down A$10.00-A$12.00 to A$170 delivered Newcastle and the new crop down to about A$152.00.
Some signs were emerging of consumer buying in the U.S., but the market continued to drop.
"Perhaps it will flop about for months," Howard said, adding that chartists were still bearish.
The next main event on Australia's wheat market calendar is the Australian Wheat Board's pool price revision, expected on Monday.
Allen said the trade expected a cut for ASW of A$5.00-A$15.00 a tonne, with the best bet A$10.00.
Suttie said pool prices were expected to be down by another A$5.00-A$10.00 after the last price cut, of A$10.00 a tonne on September 10 to A$205.00 a tonne for ASW.
Suttie pointed out that the ASW pool price, at A$205.00, less A$27.00 duty into store, stood at a net A$178, while at A$155.00 cash wheat was A$20-A$23 less than the pool.
The AWB's indicative price for new crop ASW wheat delivered Newcastle fell by A$15.00 to A$158.00 over the week.
Australian wheat futures mostly fell over the week, especially toward weekend.
The January 1997 contract settlement price fell to A$163.50 on Friday from Monday's close of A$168.50.
A slightly more active week on the SFE produced 149 futures contract trades, while 20 call options and 10 put options traded.
